elements.2211.03027_537cf5ce059f7e850ec576f3b67fd: Reinforcement learning (RL) operating on attack graphs leveraging cyber terrain principles are used to develop reward and state associated with determination of surveillance detection routes (SDR)
elements.2211.03027_bb4173591dcfb642edce07ab43087: This work extends previous efforts on developing RL methods for path analysis within enterprise networks
elements.2211.03027_f3e720b5706adfe776706646e479e: This work focuses on building SDR where the routes focus on exploring the network services while trying to evade risk
elements.2211.03027_e9ccf383392c2200e75495296f002: RL is utilized to support the development of these routes by building a reward mechanism that would help in realization of these paths
elements.2211.03027_8995de6306223f7aa02ead4bfe199: The RL algorithm is modified to have a novel warm-up phase which decides in the initial exploration which areas of the network are safe to explore based on the rewards and penalty scale factor.
elements.2211.03027_29844ea8e20697d6ba321eff59b53: attack graphs, reinforcement learning, surveillance detection routes, SDR, cyber terrain
elements.2211.03027_c2caca5552e2a40c4bd8d2867fe9b: Reconnaissance (also called recon) in MITRE's Adversarial Tactics, Techniques, and Common Knowledge (ATT
elements.2211.03027_a107bc6b875992c87cce8e1df6003: ) framework is described as "techniques that involve adversaries actively or passively gathering information that can be used to support targeting
elements.2211.03027_aae6473cc80defd541dd1e5cb5b88: ." As reconnaissance activities usually precede an exploitation campaign, detection of these efforts benefit cyber defenders by identifying potential targets (e.g., crown jewels) of interest
elements.2211.03027_d257c58d1a53aa7c13eb3dcbd32f0: In this respect, adversarial recon activities strive to maximize visibility of targets while minimizing opportunities of being detected
elements.2211.03027_abc371e968fce5ead1c56038bf4dc: Critical to this are the identification of paths, termed SDR, traversed by adversaries to gather critical data about targets (e.g., ports, protocols, applications, services)
elements.2211.03027_b8eb21a7fc1ca9e69e0131a659487: From a cyber protection standpoint, recon activities disguise serious hostile intent but may be quite difficult to quantitatively differentiate from normal behavior
elements.2211.03027_2cc941d00a19acfcbb67540a7584a: Malicious intent is quite difficult to observe, as it may be efficiently designed to hide in the background of normal traffic
elements.2211.03027_46e2e3890d73809899656ba9fa91c: Detecting this type of recon is situational in nature and requires meticulous analyses of huge volumes of collected data
elements.2211.03027_99b8d42d6fad72e9d16bd817b73c3: Other domains apart from cyber are often challenged in a similar manner, where evaluation of these SDR require data analysis to differentiate abnormal traffic from events that are suspicious in proximity to roads and crossings
elements.2211.03027_5946b494c8bcf10e536ba0f698c51: Modern efforts to detect and respond to adversarial network reconnaissance are a complicated blend of automated and human processes
elements.2211.03027_491dba6c9f3f49a207279cc480b43: Automated collection systems are installed on network devices and endpoints to passively and actively monitor the network communications, analyze the flow, and aggregate the data for the Security Information Event Management (SIEM) and/or Security Orchestration, Automation and Response (SOAR) systems for analysis
elements.2211.03027_7b05fa4fc1fb917c72a97176e31e6: These network tools assist the human component of detection by providing automated security reports, incident alerts, and executing network protection protocols with a single click from the security operations center (SOC) analyst
elements.2211.03027_276fbf8be9ce5a647230962a35b8a: The effectiveness of these systems relies on the data collected, the knowledge of current threat behavior, and the human analystâs ability to understand the threat
elements.2211.03027_2c85b550ae39e0c8d16e7e8c9a7fe: Combining the current security information (network topology and configuration) with machine learning (ML) analysis allows highlighting weak points missed by automated systems that an attacker may focus on during initial recon
elements.2211.03027_f4343905da4faf859e6b39398f5cb: Network traffic behavior analysis, no matter how advanced, relies on active network traffic and does not preempt network/host/protocol mis-configurations
elements.2211.03027_d7d63e5db088151fa77b0535ad355: This paper contributes a deep RL approach to generating SDR in the form of attack graphs from network models consisting of network topology and configuration, thereby extending the suite of automated tools and systems available for the cyber defense.
elements.2211.03027_0bd7e68ccfa01e25ff342bfa0c5db: In particular, an Markov decision process (MDP) formulation and a new algorithm, SDR-RL, is proposed that uses a warm-up phase and penalty scaling to control the asymmetry between the number of host services scanned and the number of defensive terrain encountered
elements.2211.03027_3103ba53bebf9d3710e87b567aa51: This emulates the asymmetry sought by human operators when conducting network reconnaissance generally and SDR in particular
elements.2211.03027_43db115c9ca726c013acf9aed22a9: Additionally, this paper extends the double agent architecture (DAA) of Nguyen et al.
elements.2211.03027_6a18a06a914277ee9b2703b2a1d6e: , which originally used standard deep Q-learning (DQN), with actor-critic (A2C) and proximal-policy optimization (PPO) algorithms
elements.2211.03027_2608fa523f70f6aefe2d5290447f4: This paper is structured as follows
elements.2211.03027_d09f15e44060062f83a196ec75281: First, background on RL and penetration testing is given
elements.2211.03027_cc7437d9018eeeeee5a8643f44d91: Then, the methods used to expose SDR using RL, attack graphs, and cyber terrain are presented
elements.2211.03027_8261fa4851c218d2427d3edbf98ca: Next, experimental design for testing the presented methodology is given, including details regarding RL implementation and training
elements.2211.03027_67eebb25b8f125c37ea8682a90987: Results are presented, and, before concluding, an in depth discussion is given in terms of cyber-specific outcomes.
elements.2211.03027_8b05e3fc93a1d86cafd3cdd174cf9: Reinforcement learning (RL) problems involve an agent, interacting with an environment, and transiting from one state to another until it reaches the goal state
elements.2211.03027_9370fc43526c668ed328c1926268b: The agent receives rewards for taking actions with the overall goal to achieve maximum cumulative rewards
elements.2211.03027_7b2b8d933eada2f02d1d0378d2c0b: Environments are normally modeled as MDPs, which can be defined by a tuple
elements.2211.03027_12eba3b318ddd6fd72568efcf50d8: where S denotes the set of possible states and A denotes the set of possible actions, R represents the distribution of reward given any state-action pair, P represents transition probability and
elements.2211.03027_7b6a54815764be40daec3490b9180: The goal of the agent is to learn an optimal policy
elements.2211.03027_a7924c854784da34f3e6f24df3622: As so, the RL algorithm is to learn an optimal policy to select actions and maximize the expected cumulative discounted reward:
elements.2211.03027_61543c78a2ce5caf6c090314cfb33: In (deep) Q-learning, the optimal policy can be defined by two terms, the value function and Q-value function
elements.2211.03027_c3667868152edd7134b58d2c0bc00: The value function shows how good the state is and it is defined as the expected cumulative reward from following the policy from the state
elements.2211.03027_c33afc7f65cf7535a8768e1679ece: The Q-value function, on the other side, is defined as the expected cumulative reward given both parts of the state-action pair
elements.2211.03027_1c8367a33e7190903732a828313c6: corresponds to taking the best action in any state as specified by
elements.2211.03027_47785cc5ad243d2092e433020b8f8: For a more complex problem where the state or action space is large enough so that computing every state-action pair is infeasible, neural networks become a powerful function estimator in deep Q-learning (DQL)
elements.2211.03027_f44f561581035a270d66da9876154: The optimal Q-values are estimated by a neural network parameterized by
elements.2211.03027_034236e5f38454c1c6b0cc22e39f2: During the backward pass, the gradients can be calculated as
elements.2211.03027_51062765e96c384f7ec2e68b50be1: Though RL has been pursued as a tool for penetration testing recently, the approaches to model the network vary significantly
elements.2211.03027_86cfc2ff0f57b6c356f604d8b4d0a: Alternative methods to modeling penetration testing including hypothesis generation, ontology-based, attack trees and attack graphs
elements.2211.03027_c7be22a26fc8afa5b7be268a50d2d: is an organizational network presentation for cyber defense while ontology-based models
elements.2211.03027_208e2f09a262dbbd36fbe33217c32: focus more on the semantics of penetration testing
elements.2211.03027_b58635fc95d51da0cdb5d462ee1a8: However, neither of them contains any structural information about the network itself
elements.2211.03027_34caec6fbf93db4d73e6dac18226b: and attack graphs do provide structural representation of the network, attack graphs are more generative and attack trees are special cases of attack graphs
elements.2211.03027_2ff5af781fea3e85f2e8665d83bcf: As a result, attack graph are the most recognized method for the modeling of penetration testing environment
elements.2211.03027_070103b72664b632f1a820554e6dc: The use of deep RL for attack graphs has seen recent development
elements.2211.03027_c278fb76fe4d6b50dbc3a7bada87d: , the authors in the RL for attack graphs literature use fully observable MDPs to model networks
elements.2211.03027_fd53fcf3ddfbd4f70e631ee3ef480: Many authors use the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) to furnish their MDPs (CVSS-MDPs)
elements.2211.03027_07dbf50f2131b2cd2266b20fabb8e: Yousefi et al. provide the earliest work doing so in deep RL for penetration testing
elements.2211.03027_2b5f102cbb3a0c0e22c911cb3597c: Hu et al. extend the use of the CVSS by proposing to use exploitability scores weight rewards
elements.2211.03027_4a05a7f2788bb830767307db7c353: explicitly extend the methods of Hu et al. with concepts of terrain
elements.2211.03027_596c3b2bdb15c93ca73fcaf22be01: Gangupantulu et al. advocate defining models of terrain in terms of the rewards and transition probabilities of MDPs, first in the case of firewalls as obstacles
elements.2211.03027_fbb5bda515a51c2a25c84e45be28d: , then in the case of lateral pivots nearby key terrain
elements.2211.03027_6af6dd28b04bacd3dc6fcf91bda63: Cody et al. apply these concepts to exfiltration
elements.2211.03027_581a7e4d7396464a8c69ea0885732: Other authors either handcraft the MDP or do not remark on how its components are estimated
elements.2211.03027_8f2a5aebe73b66be22a17d0a01e41: Many authors apply generic deep Q learning (DQN)
elements.2211.03027_4e9db3a3161b91eb6748ae39f2ccf: to solve point-to-point network traversal tasks
elements.2211.03027_d43c797cc14af1a08ab1a0cc472b3: Typically the terminal state is unknown and solutions take the form of individual paths
elements.2211.03027_38708db74dc6e21b28889b5fef590: Others develop domain-specific modifications for deep RL including the double agent architecture
elements.2211.03027_c0b8781d6f8789e93f64bceb70b97: , and various improvements to DQN termed NDSPI-DQN
elements.2211.03027_ff25a025fb93063c22e876c1e4bfb: Another line of research focuses on developing more specific penetration testing tasks
elements.2211.03027_1887963e267afc963426008691be9: A number of authors define more specific tasks by reward engineering and other modifications to the MDP including formulations of capture the flag
elements.2211.03027_ee1fe6d234d6ab183f0e4e6337601: This paper extends this line of research with a methodology for exposing SDR.
elements.2211.03027_22d179c0a8831f5f1d38485aec63b: The following subsections describe the presented methods for adding service-based risk penalties as defensive terrain in CVSS-MDPs and the algorithm for discovering surveillance paths in a network.
elements.2211.03027_5ee1b2264732ef6948ca36ff7e7b3: proposed that cyber terrain can be modeled into CVSS-MDPs by adding transition probabilities for traversing firewalls and negative rewards for different protocols
elements.2211.03027_de6f97dcc334484795dafae7162e8: later modeled the services-based defensive terrain in CVSS-MDPs based on the assumption that the attackers can infer the presence of defenses terrain based on the services running on a host
elements.2211.03027_9433b9ad42ec09c0617d3957b411c: We adopt their methods and classify the services into four categories: authentication, data, security and common
elements.2211.03027_b091d930fbc4c87b7aba3a6dea19c: Our reward hierarchy assigns -6 for authentication, -4 for data and -2 for security and common
elements.2211.03027_820bf530d103c65d692a3d1b3362f: Moreover, the type of actions has an effect on the rewards. n+1 (-1, -3 and -5) is assigned for scanning action while n (-2, -4 and -6) is assigned for exploiting action.
elements.2211.03027_468c72fc9ae674883f5ee3d9e3412: In our surveillance detection routes (SDR) algorithm (Algorithm 1), we have a target node of interest which we want to explore all the services running on it
elements.2211.03027_03ab52b41e7edec1f5110e93d7a3d: The goal of SDR is to gain the service information of the target node along with maximizing service information discovery along other areas of the network while being cautious and not triggering any defensive terrain area
elements.2211.03027_38be16b0d126bf48fb9ce0c8d6f65: We give a discovery reward of 100 to the target node when all its service have been discovered
elements.2211.03027_7cd23f4bbc067f74367295f9696ee: To encourage the service discovery the agent receives a +1 reward for each service discovered on a node
elements.2211.03027_7423137b9405cb82465095f297eaa: The algorithm is divided into two phases - a warm-up phase and a training phase.
elements.2211.03027_38348ee48dff0322c87d39dacb718: In the warmup phase, we want to update our goal for the RL agent to not only gain information of just the target node but also other nodes from where we receive positive reward indicating that the defense terrain allows us to access this area
elements.2211.03027_4e9b412067773a689700e634ef547: The following steps are taken in the warmup phase:
elements.2211.03027_708bdad58ff95018a53bf2f5fa858: We define a certain number of episodes for warmup phase in the training configuration.
elements.2211.03027_0eeddc8ac4f62d6f39353f5295df4: In the warmup episodes the RL agent does not learn (no weight updates) but only monitors positive reward during an episode.
elements.2211.03027_1028649d7ee28b5b50034db9871b2: If the RL agent receives a positive reward from a scanning action, then that node is added to the goal along with the target node and its reward for compromise is set to 100.
elements.2211.03027_97909f8c15e5bdcb315230e2cd0c1: The algorithm allows only one node (which gives out the maximum positive reward) from each subnet to be part of the goal as gaining control of one node in a subnet is enough to gain service information of the entire subnet.
elements.2211.03027_e60b558e6a20a9dee17f46bf96791: At the end of the warmup phase, we have these dynamic nodes along with the target node of which we must gain the service information to reach the goal
elements.2211.03027_3746ed351625059deb91ec1957154: The number of dynamic nodes being a part of the goal decreases as the scale value of defense terrain increases
elements.2211.03027_fc484712e4913139f139f5b638098: Therefore, we limit the agentâs exploration capability as we increase the scale value of defense terrain.
elements.2211.03027_6ba94d56fc141c428dc4670b4b8ee: In the training phase, the agent interacts with network in an episodic fashion to learn which is the best possible path to gain service information of all the target nodes identified during the warmup phase.
elements.2211.03027_25159c2cf62d8de8b49dc6b1d7d5e: Conventionally, DQN is the most basic algorithm used for modeling RL on penetration testing
elements.2211.03027_1346d0d42536f60302ba2dd998c03: Nguyen at al. proposed a method that utilizes two A2C agents: one called the structural agent that learns the structural information about subnets, hosts and firewalls as well as the connections between them
elements.2211.03027_2801657ea9f27f7efcc61fa91613b: The other called the exploiting agent selects actions to take and the target of them
elements.2211.03027_19e65001d6e8fd4a0b6b449485b8e: Their method solves the scalability problem of DQN to some extent and has a better capacity for large networks
elements.2211.03027_d3379c36186d04025f36a3942847e: We improve upon this method by applying proximal policy optimization (PPO) instead of A2C for both of the agents
elements.2211.03027_56f665dcfdcc8bec5574c48a8ba59: PPO is an advanced RL algorithm known for its convergence speed, stability and sample efficiency
elements.2211.03027_b34b6ad6f008e27cf9c306b140837: It optimizes the following clipped surrogate objective function to prevent performance collapse caused by a large policy update:
elements.2211.03027_e5f309c2b15d5c246f0609df8a2e8: is the probability ratio of the new policy over the old policy
elements.2211.03027_f44c2626b9cbe07ddefacbeba6ea7: is often estimated using the generalized advantage estimation
elements.2211.03027_7234684a786e130eb079fbfcada19: In the following subsections the network, state-action space, and RL algorithm implementation are described.
elements.2211.03027_c396fe7509f41c79cbca47296bd09: The same network framework as in Cody et al
elements.2211.03027_165910818867d71834f2c20eb5cec: is used for our experiment but with different configurations in defense mechanism
elements.2211.03027_f1f840833a745be5acd71b2107559: To simulate real-world network conditions, there are layers of defenses between the Internet and the innermost private network
elements.2211.03027_25d1609cba0f3e80decde25cc7506: Systems that require Internet to provide service (HTTP, email) are most vulnerable to attack; and are typically in the Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) with limited access to private network resources
elements.2211.03027_1bff678014e9f7e5748ea9a7fd768: The private, internal networks are separated from the DMZ with firewalls that apply rules that only allow connections to specific internal servers/services
elements.2211.03027_c56d71162919c742bfd4f40826b3a: VPN services to the internal network is protected with VPN Management Firewalls that apply network rules allowing only authorized and authenticated user traffic to traverse internally over an encrypted connection
elements.2211.03027_08a1183bc9285e043a41953ceaad5: Internal network subnets are separated based on access rules and allow traffic to egress to the Internet if it is authorized, as well as applying rules for network traversal between subnets
elements.2211.03027_bfc8dd6159c966a0431aa6a6a3ddf: Finally, access to the innermost subnet is controlled by a firewall that allows only authorized traffic in or out, and only to specific hosts
elements.2211.03027_0b51273eecd775838b429ddf1d8f9: These security controls were known and applied by the designers but were intentionally left unknown to the model to provide an accurate simulation of an attacker exploring an unknown network environment.
elements.2211.03027_afad6c40a3699b960992a099f2be7: The hosts are each represented as an 1D vector that encodes its status (compromised, reachable, discovered or not) and configurations (address, services, OS and processes)
elements.2211.03027_7ab2619b5aa92cb42652c88384c44: Next, our environment combines all vectors of hosts in the network as a entire state tensor
elements.2211.03027_86d34b61024daee3910ee48ba3aa5: Our action space contains 6 primitive actions for scanning, exploiting and privilege escalation
elements.2211.03027_dd68ceacfcf279939c9a3d4f8a490: For these experiments, the initial host is set at (1, 0) while the terminal host is set as (3, 1), (8, 2) or (9, 2)
elements.2211.03027_38da4aae214cd82b0b3ef95a240cc: Here, the host (x, y) refers to the host indexed by
elements.2211.03027_45e2d0ec06fec2eddbc73fa63580b: The initial host is compromised, reachable and discovered by default so that it allows the agent to perform further exploration, thus the simulation assumes the attacker already has gained this foothold in the network
elements.2211.03027_29ca2e5e0e033ccd036a6e9c61c5c: The goal of SDR is to explore all the services of the target host
elements.2211.03027_0be78c9b09ed74d4f8e37ddc8d84a: And a high positive reward (100) is assigned if the goal is reached.
elements.2211.03027_c92e0da60a838dd71560522c6fddd: The experiment is conducted on the single-agent A2C model and two variants of the double agent (DA) architecture
elements.2211.03027_b1d377afc2d12911bfe1713cae249: In the original double agent model, DA-A2C, both the structuring and the exploiting agents are trained using the A2C algorithm
elements.2211.03027_ce41294714b7678801929d9b5a7cf: To achieve better sample efficiency and training stability, we combine the PPO algorithm
elements.2211.03027_414983e367a11f89e0e4c79d48909: with the DA architecture and build a DA-PPO model, where both RL agents are trained using PPO.
elements.2211.03027_4c48a67a42b354721f327afb05006: We use Adam as the optimizer of our network
elements.2211.03027_89a02f6affb183c0e6663e8de5ab9: The A2C model is trained for 4000 episodes and the two double agent models are trained for 8000 episodes with a maximum of 3000 steps in each episode
elements.2211.03027_ee957830f322ddf4d2493c79e7e73: The episode terminates either when the goal is reached or when the step limit is reached
elements.2211.03027_c942d969aebc9779a6262eef78f91: Both the A2C model and the structuring agent of the DA models use deep neural networks (DNNs) with three fully connected layers of 64, 32 and 1 and the exploiting agent of the DA models use a DNN with two fully connected layers of size 10 and 1
elements.2211.03027_eca218599c777011a71ac9b6c307f: All DNNs use tanh activation functions for non-output layers and softmax for the output layer.
elements.2211.03027_5ac635388b67f62650a7d0f18dfef: We train the A2C, DA-A2C, DA-PPO to convergence
elements.2211.03027_139d2c550b8f7de7f08a0641015b9: Our surveillance detection algorithm is run on four different scales values namely 1, 3, 5 and 11 for host (9,2) (8,2), and (3,1)
elements.2211.03027_9bbd5ab35230e74330ad5d908579c: For host (9,2) and (8,2) we run an extra scale of 15
elements.2211.03027_f76c3227fa331b954ba67cd640039: The scale values were experimental in nature and each scale defines a certain drop in exploration of the network
elements.2211.03027_b06cedb293d2842f86ca8e4caea02: When the scale value increases, the agent becomes more risk-averse and thus keeps on reducing the amount of exploration.
elements.2211.03027_04e96114e6f4905e35f80824dff63: The model convergence is showcased by plotting the steps and reward versus episodes and results are shown in Figure
elements.2211.03027_1b914b40413f1132b742e42bed897: As can be seen from Figure
elements.2211.03027_8512e82f16764bd3b2388f1ecd799: , DA-PPO trains significantly faster than DA-A2C on all five penalty scales, both in terms of wall-time and number of episodes
elements.2211.03027_dae427785d53eb278c52f89979eac: Specifically, DA-PPO converges in less than ten minutes as compared to more than 30 minutes by DA-A2C (Figure
elements.2211.03027_355e64f962bd176193c7c1ef6bb83: ), and it requires much fewer episodes to learn an effective policy (Figure
elements.2211.03027_81f99c69906920fd786b173e618cd:

elements.2211.03027_ae03cf299536ed34a1dc8a87cf420: The DAA modeling highlights a pattern that showed the expected path being taken at all the penalty scales for all the three different target host, minimizing the number of defenses crossed
elements.2211.03027_07708861657b1195c3e3538332d79: While the path converges by taking a relative higher number of episodes, it thus offers higher scalability while applying it to real world use cases with larger networks
elements.2211.03027_04d7ef50dacf8b73f196cda2969be: Across the models, it is observed that as the penalty keeps on increasing the agent reduces the amount of exploration and only explored areas which are deemed to be safe
elements.2211.03027_7390c705358270cac662d9daed641: The simpler A2C model followed the expected path being taken in penalty scale of 1, 11 and 15 for three different target host
elements.2211.03027_cb253ac71638dfe2b3f10a2e84073: However, for scale of 3 and 5 in target host of (3,1), the A2C Model takes a potential imperfect path which expose to a higher risk; this suggests that even for a small test network of this size, a simpler agent scheme fails to find realistic paths.
elements.2211.03027_197faff85e6b4fdec9aeec3799d4a: We can observe the paths taken by the agent to achieve the SDR goal when target hosts are (8,2) and (3,1) for penalty scales 1, 3 and 11 in Fig 3
elements.2211.03027_ce42437d7a078b38f723f4ec006ca: In Table 1, we can observe that as we are adjusting the scale factor the number of services being explored drops off
elements.2211.03027_faa7e6829292fb20458d4fb3804b2: Furthermore, the number of high penalty host controlled goes down from 2 to 1 as we scaled the penalty showcasing that the agent becomes more risk averse
elements.2211.03027_73cb600cab4a405b907d415edc4f3: For penalty scale 1, the agent takes a path which according to the environment and penalty is acceptable as in its exploration of network it is taking control of hosts which are either low or medium risk except one high penalty host (i.e., (4,0)) which is a necessity as to reach the goal at least one high-risk host needs to be controlled
elements.2211.03027_506e9e8380cd2b60b06bfd4e3dde9: Therefore, the path taken by the agent for a low penalty of 1 is acceptable
elements.2211.03027_39f961d50ec0ad084ec0703e29ed7: For penalty scale 3, when the target is (8,2) the agent takes an acceptable path according to the environment and penalty as it takes control of only low penalty host except one high penalty host (i.e., (4,0)) which is again a necessity to explore services on the target host
elements.2211.03027_8b4d2a8652ab65bc4c9d1e24c642f: However, when the target host is (3,1), the agent takes a path which is less acceptable according to the environment and penalty as it takes control of two high penalty node (i.e., (4,0) and (3,0)) where only one was required to achieve the goal
elements.2211.03027_a7223943c19006829ebc287e53908: The agent had an option to select (3,2) which is a lower penalty host than (3,0)
elements.2211.03027_e1b05a6b3409dc4162e86b6e591af: For penalty scale 11, the agent takes a path which is acceptable according the state and penalty of the environment and takes control of host which are low risk apart from only one high risk host which is unavoidable in achieving the goal
elements.2211.03027_e3a022da7149177c9faecad0542b0: Associating penalty scores (low to high) to the risk adversity of human actors demonstrates that the agent performs actions that are reasonably in line with expected human advisory behavior
elements.2211.03027_d64681ea12937b76c6eb17c242c94: Actors operating in a condensed timeline, commonly referred as âsmash and grabâ operations, or actors without sufficient experience, would be examples of an agent set with a Penalty Scale of 1.0
elements.2211.03027_eeb2db78011a391ea564e5463c05a: Nation-State actors, highly-competent APTs (Advanced Persistent Threats), and experienced actors with more time to observe and a higher cost of getting caught would be representative of an agent with a penalty scale of 11.0
elements.2211.03027_b65b43445809bf801549a385c1064: When risk adversity is low, an actor is not worried about performing ânoisyâ scans
elements.2211.03027_8a01ec6f1e7e2c4d7fbffa8acb1a6: These scans will include enumeration of multiple network services or simultaneously traversing multiple network segments (with each new segment potentially having deeper layers of defense incorporated into it)
elements.2211.03027_852e0467c90d7b079cfa3aee35b81: As observed when the penalty score is set to one (1.0), the agent finds and explores paths that would involve a higher level of risk of getting caught and a lower sensitivity to negative consequences
elements.2211.03027_e2bded8c64be25fb1a47eef73dd8a: These actions involve scanning or traversing paths with a reasonable presumption of greater security and more rigorously logged and monitored network devices, such as VPNs and Firewalls (FW) (High Risk Hosts) as well as enumerating networks not directly associated with the respective target
elements.2211.03027_a58b277aa3ca5a26f336fe1f26d50: The risk-accepting paths also explored several networks unnecessarily and utilize multiple services along the way
elements.2211.03027_54a337067416b7d00f5fcfc174c75: Each service to be used and/or exploited along the way creates another risk and/or protection system that may be in place, thus increasing the log presence and actor footprint. (As stated above, it is presumed that firewalls are monitored at a higher rate, and that security services have the most inherited controls.) While exploitation of these devices yields great impact, the associated risk is also higher
elements.2211.03027_f1b7d292fab946200b76cd3670c77: This risky behavior is reflected by the agent as seen in Table 1 with the larger number of services and high penalty hosts being exploited, as well as represented by the paths chosen in Figure 3
elements.2211.03027_fb8b62ee3eb4f46499f207f0aaede: When risk adversity is high, the cost of getting caught outweighs the reward of network discovery, so actors, and as observed, the agent, take the most direct path possible
elements.2211.03027_5cd860fbf45c01c7daa0938a558ac: Risk adverse actors naturally choose paths that avoid traversing multiple protocols/services and presumed increased security controls
elements.2211.03027_a820e3d4fb1778852995042bb71f6: This lowers the log footprint and network noise generated and reduces the chances of detection
elements.2211.03027_55929a77d5617e198e8036f1857d7: The agentâs behavior of only taking control of one high risk host to reach the lower target reflects the lowest risk path that an advisory would naturally gravitate to.
elements.2211.03027_ed50702dce65dd997a759e3ca41d9: In this work, we provide a RL realization of automating analysis methods for SDR
elements.2211.03027_05d0f81cb432afe0394c7986e1614: Our approach introduces a warm-up phase to perform pre-exploration emulating an experienced actors necessity to find the
elements.2211.03027_bb633095fa0728c3fc999d12b35de: The capability and efficiency of our methods are validated by simulations on a custom network configured with defense mechanisms (simulated cyber range)
elements.2211.03027_27f86e09827ebd88f388bf489f080: The model ran on a network created to simulate the realistic placement of layered network defenses with increasing security controls as an actor draws closer to the most sensitive information and services
elements.2211.03027_b2690b578c8cf9c9ae902d8ae0fd0: As the model was faced with penalties that increased when transitioning into more secure zones, the effect of the penalty score became more demonstrative
elements.2211.03027_9cd197437ed1186e496e13f9d7a3f: This activity mirrors the expected risk sensitivity of an actor mirroring the risk profile of the model's penalty score
elements.2211.03027_70bee2c2f38837cfa692f67bb701a: A more risk/penalty adverse model showed significantly more concise paths to reach the goal, while the less risk-adverse model explored around and left more of a footprint on the defense systemâs logs
elements.2211.03027_19b66890b2022aa26e3ce93383a54: In future work, we expect to run this model on a live network utilizing both internal and external network data
elements.2211.03027_bf0cbf3eb317087f08f4615177825: Incorporating internal and external scan information allows for a model that most-closely mimics a malicious actor and defensive expectations for their actions
elements.2211.03027_a9a867fd545eb983b9e78d3d13563: Using live data for a production network should also create greater granularity for the penalty scoring as vulnerability data for CVSS3 and weakness data for associated Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) can be incorporated.
